properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Wednesday. Lake effect snow bands are expected to develop overnight and persist through the day Wednesday. Travel may be impacted, particularly on Highway 17, due to low visibility in heavy snow at times. Conditions are forecast to improve Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T19:04:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T03:05:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0949700844.2019
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Weakening lake effect snow squalls early this morning. Flurries and snow squalls are forecast to continue early this morning, but will continue to weaken with time. Local blowing snow causing reduced visibilities will continue be a concern early this morning. Local snowfall amounts of 20 to 30 cm are expected by the time the snow squalls taper off this morning. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-14T00:59:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T09:47:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3286011555.2019
Area: Owen Sound - Blue Mountains - Northern Grey County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Lake effect flurries and local snow squalls are expected to develop Wednesday midday and persist through Thursday morning. Local snowfall accumulations of 15 to 25 cm will be possible Wednesday night with an additional 5 centimetres possible Thursday before the squalls move out of the area. Snow squall warnings will likely be required. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T19:10:01-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T03:11:01-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0700862798.2019
Area: Bayfield Inlet - Dunchurch, Bruce Peninsula - Sauble Beach - Tobermory
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Additional snowfall amounts from 5 to 10 centimetres are expected by Wednesday morning. The snow will be accompanied by strong winds reducing visibilities in blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-11-13T18:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-11-13T04:01:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2671069840.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain will continue across Nova Scotia this evening, then change to to flurries late tonight or Wednesday morning as cold westerly winds move into the region and temperatures quickly fall below freezing. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries push eastward across the province. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall amounts: 5 to 15 cm, highest amounts inland. Locations: Cartwright and south to Lodge Bay. Time span: Continuing through to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow will transition to rain from south to north overnight into Wednesday morning with a period of freezing rain likely over inland areas. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected inland and over higher terrain, particularly along the Trans-Labrador Highway, where temperatures will be slower to rise. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls tonight into Wednesday morning. Flurries and local snow squalls continue tonight. Local snowfall amounts to near 15 cm will be possible by Wednesday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities to near zero will also be a concern. The local snow squalls are forecast to come to an end when the winds shift to southwest later Wednesday morning. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Lake effect snow squalls expected Wednesday. Southerly winds over the relatively warm waters of Lake Superior are expected to produce flurries and local snow squalls on Wednesday. The squalls could start as early as Wednesday morning and are expected to continue through Wednesday night. Local snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are possible on Wednesday, however areas closer to Lake Superior could see locally higher amounts of 15 to 25 cm. Additional amounts of 5 to 15 cm are possible Wednesday night into Thursday morning. Local blowing snow reducing visibilities will also be a concern. Local snow squalls are forecast to taper off when the winds shift to the northwest on Thursday. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

Snow will be accompanied with north to northeasterly winds gusting to 50 or 60 km/h, resulting in blowing snow over exposed areas. Over eastern areas of the Trans-Labrador Highway in the Eagle River forecast region, a period of freezing rain is expected this morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls possible late today into tonight. Strong and cold westerly winds blowing over relatively warm Gulf waters will make conditions favourable for the development of snow squalls late this afternoon into this evening. Conditions will become unfavourable for snow squalls by Thursday morning as a ridge of high pressure moves over the Maritimes. Driving conditions will become hazardous due to snow, blowing snow, and high winds. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain is forecast to continue into this morning, with total forecast rainfall accumulations ranging from 40 to 60 millimetres over the region. The rain will change to flurries this morning as cold westerly winds move across the province. Flurries will persist through the day and into tonight, when conditions will become favourable for the development of snow squalls. A snow squall watch has been issued for this evening and overnight. Driving conditions will be hazardous, with high winds and snow, as well as blowing snow in exposed areas this afternoon into tonight. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: up to 110 km/h tonight. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik. Time span: today until Thursday morning. Remarks: The snow will be accompanied by strong north to northeasterly winds gusting up to 80 km/h today giving reduced visibilities in blowing snow. Winds will further increase from the north to northwest tonight, with local gusts of 110 km/h expected, causing blizzard like conditions. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-11-14T01:17:41-00:00

Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. Total rainfall: 50 to 80 mm. Locations: southwestern Newfoundland from Channel-Port aux Basques to Grey River. Time span: continuing until late this morning. Remarks: Further rainfall amounts of up to 15 mm are expected before the rain tapers off later this morning. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Rainfall warnings are issued when significant rainfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Fog Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Near zero visibility in fog is expected or occurring. Fog has formed in the Grande Prairie and Whitecourt-Edson regions and is expected to persist until Wednesday morning. This advisory may be expanded to surrounding areas. ### Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

Locations: Bay St. George up to the Bay of Islands Time span: continuing until late this morning. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Temperatures have dropped below freezing for most of the Island as cold westerly winds move into the region. Driving conditions may become difficult as the cold air and flurries move in. A snow squall watch has been issued for eastern regions of the Island for this evening and overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
